Award.AwardTitle: Analyzing the Role of Yeast Telomere Capping Proteins in Coordinating Terminal Replication

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. Maintaining the genome in the form of linear chromosomes poses significant challenges for eukaryotic cells. In particular, how to fully duplicate the chromosome termini (telomeres) and how to prevent sequence loss or inappropriate rearrangements at telomeres are critical issues. Key factors involved in solving these problems include the telomerase enzyme, which adds short G-rich repeats to one DNA strand of the telomere, and capping proteins that bind to telomeric sequences. Telomerase compensates for loss of telomeric sequences during replication, while capping proteins afford protection from enzymes that would otherwise degrade, unwind, or inappropriately recombine the ends. Interestingly, the DNA replication machinery, and the polymerase alpha-primase complex (Pol alpha) in particular, has been shown to have functional and physical connections with both telomerase and telomere capping activities. Based on this, the goal of this project is to understand at a molecular level how the function of telomere capping proteins and telomerase are coordinated with the DNA replication machinery. The budding yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, will be used to investigate three issues that are relevant to this goal. First, do the telomere capping proteins Cdc13, Stn1 and Ten1 recruit Pol alpha; to newly extended telomeres? Second, do Cdc13, Stn1 and Ten1 enhance terminal replication fork progression or stability? Third, does Pol alpha; negatively regulate the processivity of telomerase? Answers to these questions have the potential to significantly expand our understanding of the mechanisms that coordinate telomere replication and telomere capping, and will undoubtedly provide insights that can be further tested in other organisms.

Broader Impacts. Undergraduate and graduate students will carry out this project and participate in weekly presentations and discussions of experiments and related literature. The findings will be shared through participation of the students in local, national, and international conferences as well as publication in peer-reviewed journals. Since a relatively large proportion of the student population at UCR comprises underrepresented groups in science, increasing the opportunities for hands-on research will help to broaden the participation of these groups in science, exposing them to the excitement of discovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the relationship between telomere end protection and DNA replication, probing the significance of interactions among S. ceresiviae capping proteins and polymerase alpha primase. The first objective dfsawas to test the hypothesis that the telomere capping proteins Cdc13, Stn1 and/or Ten1 promote polymerase alpha in telomere replication. The second objective was to test the hypothesis that these capping proteins enhance terminal replication fork progression or stability. 

 

We demonstrated that DNA polymerase alpha primase plays a role in limiting the repeat addition processivity of telomerase, such that when DNA polymerase alpha is compromised, more telomere repeats are added to an end by a single telomerase enzyme.  Furthermore, when polymerase alpha is impaired, telomerase extends telomere ends irrespective of their length, failing to identify or to preferentially extend critically short ends.  Our findings are consistent with the model that association of DNA pol alpha with telomeres, or synthesis of the complementary strand of telomere repeats, inhibits elongation by telomerase.  These findings advance the field’s understanding of how telomerase activity can be limited, and support a model where Cdc13 can continue to promote telomere extension by telomerase if it is not associated with polymerase alpha.   

 

Our experimental approaches to the second objective led to a very surprising story that significantly impacts multiple fields.  When assessing the role of Cdc13, Stn1 and Ten1 in replication we found that, contrary to expectation, Stn1 and Ten1 do not function exclusively at telomeres, but are required for global genome stability.  DNA damage foci in mutant stn1 and ten1 strains were found at both telomeric and non-telomeric sites.  Interestingly, investigating DNA synthesis across all chromosomes revealed that Stn1 has a role promoting replication origin firing – a step in DNA replication that is necessary to allow DNA unwinding and synthesis.  Mechanistically, we found that Stn1 promotes the function of a key S phase kinase, the DDK, in targeting the replicative helicase for activation. Through the use of specific genetic mutants, we further demonstrated that this role of Stn1 is important for maintaining genetic integrity throughout the genome. The Stn1-DDK connection is new and unexpected, and the results substantially alter models for Stn1 function, as well as add to models for regulation of the DDK and replication origin firing. 

 

Intellectual merit:  This work significantly contributes to understanding how Cdc13, Stn1 and Ten1 capping proteins function in regulating telomere extension by telomerase, and DNA replication activities both at termini and globally.  Discovering that Stn1 positively regulates DNA replication, and uncovering the mechanistic basis for this function, substantially advances both the telomere and DNA replication fields, with potential to impact future understanding of how DNA replication is regulated under stress or in particular chromosomal contexts. The work investigating how the Cdc13, Stn1 and Ten1 proteins act with polymerase alpha to regulate telomere extension by telomerase adds to the field’s understanding of how telomerase accesses telomeres, and how telomere extension can be limited in cells.  

 

Broader impacts: Diverse teams of graduate and undergraduate students carried out this project, learning how to design, execute, analyze and present research findings.  They also learned mentoring skills, as the more senior students were leaders and teachers for newer students.  Critical thinking skills were honed in journal clubs where students presented research papers for discussion.  Our work is being shared to a wide scientific audience through scientific conferences and publications.  To reach out to the local community and encourage excitement about science and the scientific process, we helped start a science fair at a local elementary school, where the majority of students are from underrepresented and lower socioeconomic groups. To help students think about how to develop science projects from questions connected to their surroundings and observations, each year we presented school assemblies that included fun science demonstrations. Materials and rubrics were also developed to help the teachers guide students. Since the school has a Spanish dual-immersion curriculum, we conducted judging in Spanish as appropriate.  Our consensus was that the overall quality of projects the students presented improved each year over three years, with more unique projects and seemingly better teacher guidance.
